titleStmt.title: St Endellion

editor.orgName: Maynooth University, Department of Early Irish
Maynooth University, Department of Early Irish

titleStmt.funder: Irish Research Council (grant no. IRC/W001985/1) and Arts and Humanities Research Council (grant no. AH/W001985/1)

funder.ref: UK-Ireland Collaboration in the Digital Humanities Research Grant

msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in ogham script

support.p: Historic Environment Record ID: Hob UID: 430789

supportDesc.condition: An inscribed stone in two pieces and cemented onto a circular base (Okasha 1993, 232). The stone is weatherworn and covered by a dense growth of lichen (Macalister 1945, 457). The Latin inscription consists of two vertical lines, Macalister described the first line as "clear, though worn" and the second line as "having been chamfered away by weathering" to such an extent that "only the tops of the letters remain" (1945, 457). Macalister observed "faint" traces of an ogham inscription "capable of being read BROCAGNI; but nothing that could be regarded with any confidence" (1945, 457). Okasha determined that there is "no sign of any ogham text today" (Okasha 1993, 235).

layoutDesc.layout: The Latin inscription is on the N. E. face of the stone. Macalister noted that the top of the stone has a chi-rho monogram with a curved foot (1945, 456). Apparently, a plain cross in relief was also cut into the back of the stone near the top but neither Macalister (1945, 456) or Okasha (1993, 232) could find any trace of it. The two lines of the Latin inscription read downwards and face left. The presence of an ogham inscription on the right-hand angle of the stone was suggested by Macalister but described as "doubtful" (1945, 457). The possibility of an ogham text was later disregarded by Okasha (1993, 235).

handDesc.handNote: Macalister surmised that the Latin inscription was "probably pocked and rubbed" (1945, 456). Okasha remarked that the script "appears to be predominantly capital in form with many ligatures" (233). Thomas noted that the inscription "shows quite a few devolved letter forms" (1994, 263). The CI of IACIT and the FI of FILIVS are ligatured. The letters measure between 9 to 10 cm in height (Okasha 1993, 233).

origin.origPlace: St Endellion, Cornwall 50.582325, -4.841989 National Grid Reference: SW 9890 7970

history.provenance: Known locally as 'Long Cross', the stone was first recorded in 1753 by James Tregeare in a manuscript account of the Parish of Endellion. Between 1821 and 1873, the stone was moved to a very exposed place in Doyden Head where it sustained severe weathering as a result, but the base of the stone remained in situ (Macalister 1945, 456). In 1932, the Bodmin Old Cornwall Society re-erected the stone upon its base in its original location, by the road between Roscarrock and St Endellion Church, where it still stands.
On a grass island at a junction about 1.5Â km from St Endellion on the road to Port Quin.

app.rdg: Roman: BROCAGNI IHC IACIT NADOTTI FILIVS

div.p: Previous scholarship linked the first element of NADOTTI 'nad' to Irish names (Okasha 1993, 234). Similarly, the name BROCAGNI was interpreted by Jackson as either Primitive Irish or Primitive Cornish (1953, 566, 665n). Okasha noted that "the name BROCAGNI occurs on a stone from Llangeler, Wales, and in ogham on an Irish stone from Dunalis" (1993, 234). Thomas stated that the name Brocagnus is Primitive Irish, Brocagnas, meaning 'Little Badger', and is also "the same name as that of king Brychan", the "eponymous king of sixth-century Brycheiniog, which lay immediately north of Glywysing" (1994, 263; 78). Okasha dates the stone from the sixth to eighth century based on the "evidence of the monogram chi-ro symbol".
